paper_abstract: Power gating is an efficient technique for reducing the leakage power of electronic devices by disconnecting the power supply from blocks idle for long periods of time. Disconnecting gated blocks causes changes in the current densities of the grid branches and vias. For some gating configurations, dc current densities may increase in some grid locations to the extent that they violate electromigration (EM) constraints. In this paper, we analyze the EM and infrared (IR) voltage drop effects in gated global power grids. Based on our analyses, we develop a global grid sizing algorithm to satisfy the reliability constraints on grid branches and vias for all feasible gating configurations. Our experimental results indicate that a grid initially sized for all blocks connected to it may be modified to fulfill EM and IR constraints for multiple gating schedules with only a small area increase.
paper_title: Reliability Analysis and Optimization of Power-Gated ICs
